g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
This section considers technological innovation in the broader context of sustainable development,
recognising that technological change happens within social and economic systems, and therefore
technologies are conceived and applied in relation to those s
complex interactions between physical and social systems and incomplete knowledge of technological
atically lead to underestimation of environmental impacts and
overestimation of our ability to mitigate climate change
esen et al. 2011; Hertwich and Peters
In previous sections, the chapter discussed how a systemic approach, appropriate public policies and
international cooperation on innovation can enhance technological innovation. This section provides
etails on how innovation and technological change, sustainable development and climate change
Linking sustainable development and technological change
Sustainable development and technological change are deeply related
has been critical for increasing productivity as the dominant driving force for economic growth but also,
the concentration of technology in few hands has boosted consumption of goods and services which are
that, in order to address sustainable development challenges, science and technology actors would have
to change their relation to policymakers
. This has been further elaborated for the SDGs. The scale and ambition of the SDGs call for a
change in development patterns that require a fundamental shift
in both current best practices and
guidelines for technological and investment decisions and in the wider socio
. This is needed as not all innovation will lead to
Current Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) implementation gaps reflect, to some extent, inadequate
the complex relationships among the goals
offs, including how they limit the range of responses available to
communities and governments, and potential injustices
relationships have been approached by focusing primarily on synergies and trade
holistic perspective necessary to achieve all the goals
A more holistic framework could envisage the SDGs as outcomes of stakeholder engagement and
ses directed at achieving a balance between human development and environmental
, to the extent that the two can be separated. From a science,
distinguish three categories of SDGs. The
first category comprises those SDGs representing essential human needs for which inputs that put
pressure on sustainable development would need to be minimized. These include food
(SDG 6) and energy (SDG 7) resources, which continue to rely on production technologies and practices
that are eroding ecosystem services, hampering the realization of SDG goals 15 (land) and 14 (oceans)
. The second are those related to governance and which compete with each other for
scarce resources, such as infrastructure (SDG 9) and climate action (SDG 13), which require
interdisciplinary perspective. The third category are those that require maximum realization, include no
poverty (SDG 1), quality education (SDG 4) and gender equality (SDG 5)
Resolving tensions between the SDGs requires adoption and mainstreaming of novel technologies that
can meet needs while reducing resource waste and improving resource
acknowledging the systemic nature of technolo
gical innovation, which involve many levels of actors,
